Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Nicholas Day of Portland State University to conduct a research project, entitled "A light-absorbing catalyst to stimulate the conversion of carbon dioxide to methanol," during the summer of 2012 at Osaka University in Suita, Osaka. The host scientist is Dr. Shunichi Fukuzumi.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is advancing the knowledge of potential renewable energy sources. The direct focus of this research is to investigate a novel material with the potential ability to use renewable resources to produce liquid fuel which can be utilized with current infrastructure. In particular a cobalt metallated poly-tetrakis-5,10,15,20-(4-aminophenyl)porphyrin is being used to reduce carbon dioxide to methanol using only sunlight. Methanol is seen as a viable source of energy for the near future.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Also planned is a solar cell demonstration to students at Takarazuka-Kita high school. Providing education of renewable energy sources to students in Japan is highly relevant considering the high demand for new energy sources in Japan and the U.S.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Global climate change has become the largest environmental problem facing the world today. The only way to stop global climate change is complete implementation of renewable energy sources. Future energy demands can best be met through improved collection and storage of the ample solar energy reaching Earth. Researchers are turning to materials with the potential to produce chemical fuels from the sun’s energy. The direct focus of this research is to investigate a novel material with the potential ability to use carbon dioxide to produce liquid fuel which can be utilized with current infrastructure.
    The novel material used in this research is polymeric porphyrins. Porphyrins are light absorbing molecules which plants use during photosynthesis. Porphyrins can hold a metal atom in their structure, and we can change the metal atom it holds. By simply changing the metal atom in the porphyrin, the properties of the molecule change significantly.
    Initial studies performed at Portland State University show the novel material we are using has the potential to react with carbon dioxide by applying a small voltage. The research at Osaka University was primarily to determine if this same reaction could occur using only sunlight and no electricity. Polymeric porphyrins containing iron, cobalt and manganese were all tested for reactivity. Both cobalt and iron porphyrins show reactivity using only light when carbon dioxide is present.
    While working at Osaka University, we also attempted to analyze the products from the reactivity with the porphyrins and carbon dioxide.  Unfortunately, due to time and equipment constraints at Osaka University, we were unable to determine what products are being formed. Further research here at Portland State University will be conducted to determine the products. 
    Research concerning reactions with carbon dioxide is fundamentally important for multiple reasons. Limiting global climate change is the primary objective, and so far we have concentrated on the reaction of carbon dioxide to methanol to use as fuel. Another environmentally important example is the formation of organic carbonates. Industrially, 2.6 megatons of organic carbonates are used annually.1 Organic carbonates are small molecules which are used in many industries; one example is the production of aspirin. Organic carbonates are usually synthesized using phosgene gas which is both toxic and environmentally harmful. Recently, some porphyrin-like molecules with metals have been found to catalyze the formation of organic carbonates without using phosgene gas.(1) The world currently produces 24 gigatons of carbon dioxide every year, but we only use 0.1 gigatons industrially. When we discover a good route to activating carbon dioxide, we will be able to use it much more readily for numerous synthetic procedures.

References:
Mikkelsen, M.; Jørgensen, M.; Krebs, F. C. The teraton challenge. A review of fixation and transformation of carbon dioxide. Energy Environ. Sci. 2010, 3, 43–81.
